text: in the wake of terrorist violence people
demand action and governments rush to
comply sometimes this means rounding up
innocent people imprisoning them and
then refusing to admit the mistake
that's what happened with the Guildford
four who were wrongly convicted in the
1970s of involvement with an IRA
terrorist plot their case is the subject
of Jim Sheridan's film in the name of
the Father Daniel Day Lewis plays Gerry
Conlon a petty thief and general
screw-up who is framed by the British
police and imprisoned along with his
father Giuseppe played by Piet possibly
who becomes his cellmate their cause is
eventually taken up by Gareth Peirce a
lawyer played by a crusading Emma
Thompson certainly satisfying to be
roused to a state of righteous outrage
by this movie what makes it great is its
depiction of the changing relationship
between father and son
Sheridan elicits powerful and subtle
performances from these two
extraordinary actors Pete possibly and
Daniel day-lewis
I'm Santa so you've been a victim on
your life it's about time you started
the faith book at the start of the film
they're in a state of almost constant
conflict giuseppe is a modest
conservative lower middle-class family
man he's everything Gerry is rebelling
against Gerry sees Giuseppe as boring
and predictable but as their ordeal goes
on he comes to appreciate his father's
steadfastness and this change in Gerry's
understanding of his father changes him
and all my godforsaken
what I was thinking what to kill
somebody until my man Jerad common buck
on the threes day-lewis captures every
stage and nuance of this transformation
before he goes to prison Jerry is not
just angry and defiant he's also
exuberant and charming and the
maturation that happens once he's behind
bars is a slow halting painful process
you see I don't understand your language
justice mercy clemency I literally don't
understand what those words mean this is
an overpowering and inspiring
performance but it's not that Gerry
Conlon is exactly what you'd call a hero
he's a person caught up in horrific but
all-too-real circumstances and it's
day-lewis's ability to take us inside
this man's experience that makes the
sense of injustice this movie produces
so acute so personal
